Sun~AM  Good Morn ing Lt.  Boyle,  Just passing t his informatio n alo ng regarding a motor veh icle st op I had  th is past week, du ring  w hich t ime Fusion Cente r assisted me . A CJIS  query  of t he SS# revea led another party w it h t he same name, DOB, and SS#.  A Il l que ry revea led  two dif fe rent  FB I numbers.  At that point, I be lieved  I had  an "Impostor" situat ion .  I reached  out t o t he Fusion Cent er for assistance w it h facial recognition, who provided va rious OLNs  based upon t he facial recognition hits .  These OLNS are listed be low and ref lect t he same  - party using different names,  DOBs, and SS#:  - I t he n rece ived an ema il f rom PR  Police Department, w hich matched t he PR  License  holder I  had on the stop. Att ached in t his ema il are t he RMV photos from PR  and MA, as well as t he PR  License t he  passenger possessed.  Another flag t hat caught  my eye was t he PR  License itself .  The license  issue dat e was 03/21/2017.  I have a PDF  Document from t he Fraud Department in  NYPD,  w hich covers PR  Lice nses issued in 2019.  I noted a f ew in dicators of a pote nt ially forged  RMV document (missing gold star upper right  hand corner, "Not  for Rea i iD Purposes" was not  omitted, "Commonwea lt h of  Puerto Rico" rat he r t han "Government of Puert o Rico", and the  listed  height and we ight we re typed w it hout  hyphens . subject: - - Identity Fraud
body: ~st  Good afternoon Lt.  Boyle:  I am prosecuting an identity fraud case in Salem District Court. My defendant was t he passenger in a  car that was pulled over. The defendant  initially told officers that he  (DOB : - ) residing at  Officers were able to discover that this Defendant was  using a Puerto Rican social security number  . At some point during this encounter,  the Defendant  provided officers w ith a Mass ID card  ); t he number came back with no  results in Massachusetts. This ID card was allegedly issued on 12/21/2017 and did not match a  license number for the Defendant(- ) The  Defendant claimed to have been born in Puerto  Rico and had never been issued a PR driver's license. Officers also reported that the Defendant had a  New Hampshire State ID as well as a criminal history in  NH . When officers ran the Defendant's Il l,  two FBI  numbers showed w ith the same demographic information. Officers were able to get in  contact with the t  w ho was born in  PR and now resides in the US. The  Defendant event ually confessed his true identity to be  · however, facial  recognition has not come back to confirm, so it is unclear as to w hether this is t ruly the Defendant's  name. Apparently, the RMV has initiated proceedings against the Defendant  for using a false social  security number, but t he Defendant defaulted on those matters.  I understand t hat you are able to get RMV documents to assist us in identity fraud cases. I would like  to request the Defendant's RMV applications as well as any investigative documents that the RMV  has collected relative to t he Defendant's identity and use of this name/social security number. If any  of t he information I have provided you with is unclear please let me know. I can give you more  information or forward you a copy of t he police report. subject: DIABETIC TEST STRIPS suspect
body: All,   I have submitted this suspects photo to Mass Most Wanted to try and ID him.  301 has an open matter with him from   and   informed me that the value of items taken so far is above $630.00 and the suspect is using a key to defeat the security packages.  This is the suspected vehicle he’s in, it’s believed to be a Ford Explorer or Mercury Mountaineer.  If anyone receives info on who he is please contact 301 or myself.     Thanks         Team,       At approximately 0846 today the male suspect in the attached photo successfully shoplifted two containers of OneTouch test strips. The suspect has been in our store on multiple occasions doing the same thing.          The suspect enters the store, shops for nonsense items, heads to Pharmacy, selects the test strips and makes his way to Toy's. There he removes the items from the Alpha Boxes with a key (there is no sign of damage to the boxes) and conceals them on his person.          The total amount shoplifted over a 3 week period is $560. I'm pretty sure we aren't the only ones being hit. BOLO!

subject: Facial Recognition Assistance
body: Good afternoon,   My name is Ernie Butner and I am a paralegal with the Middlesex District Attorney’s Office. I hope this email finds you well.   It is my understanding that the RMV has the capability of cross-referencing images with the RMV database of photos in order to help law enforcement agencies identify unknown suspects. We have a case out of   in which we have surveillance images of a suspect but no identification, and we were hoping to make use of this facial recognition software if possible.   I have attached several stills from the surveillance image to this email. Can you please tell me if you are able to run facial recognition and, if so, whether or not these photos will suffice for this purpose?   Thank you very much. If you have any questions or concerns, or need any clarification, please feel free to let me know.   Best, Ernie   The preceding email message (including any attachments) contains information that may be confidential, may be protected by the attorney-client or other applicable privileges, or may constitute non-public information. It is intended to be conveyed only to the designated recipient(s) named above. If you are not an intended recipient of this message, please notify the sender by replying to this message and then delete all copies of it from your computer system. subject: Boston Sexual Assault-
body: Hi,   Investigators from our Sexual Assault Unit are looking to see if there is anything that you can do with the attached still photo of a suspect in a sexual assault that took place in  - see the below narrative for additional details:   At about 1:38 PM on Saturday October 8, 2016, officers assigned to  responded to a call for an attempted sexual assault in the area of the   on   Street in    On arrival, officers spoke with the adult female victim who stated that a male suspect approached her from behind on foot, threw her to the ground and attempted to sexually assault her before fleeing the area.  The suspect (shown in the above image) is described as an   male in his late 20’s, approximately 5”8,slim build, a goatee, black hair in a ponytail, with tattoos on both arms wearing black and white sneakers, black shorts and a black T-shirt with white lettering.  The suspect was later observed riding a Rincon model Giant brand mountain bike towards  Avenue. Unfortunately this is the best clip we have at this time. Probably not ideal for a hit but if there is anything that you can do we appreciate it.   -- Paul C. McLaughlin Sergeant Detective Bureau of Intelligence and Analysis Boston Police Department-Boston Regional Intelligence Center

subject: RFA
body: Good Evening,   I received a request for assistance from our ICE office at the US Embassy in    The attached DLs are people attempting to get   version of a Social Security Number, which would allow them to open bank accounts, apply for visas, and customs paperwork.   I looked at the   and immediately knew they were fake since the license number on some started with other letters than S, and also had too many numbers.  I ran the names DOB and got nothing in CJIS and III.   I was hoping to run FR on all of the attached licenses and see if we can get any hits back.   ICE is working a theory this is a ID fraud case.   Please let me know if you have any other questions.   Thank You, Brian   Brian E. body: To Whom It May Concern:     I’m reaching out to request assistance with any facial recognition process you might be able to employ to help with an on-going HSI investigation.     Through my investigation, I’ve identified a subject who may be obtaining driver’s licenses using both his real name and date of birth, and fictitious names and associated biographical information.     I have three (3) different photos of the same subject found on various driver’s licenses which I have attached to this email.  I’m hoping you might be able to run these against any facial recognition database to which you have access.     Any help you might be able to provide would be hugely appreciated.  Please do not hesitate to contact me by cell or email to clarify the nature of the request, or if any specific form or documentation is required in order to respond to this request.    My case and agency information is below, in the event you need it for bookkeeping:   Case number:     Subject name:                                     Agency ORI:         Case type:           Financial fraud - 18 USC 1028A (Agg. ID Theft); 1029 (Access Device Fraud); 1030 (Fraudulent use of a computer); 1343 (Wire Fraud); 1956(a)(1)(b) (Money laundering)     Respectfully,

subject: Norwood MA PD search warrant and Impostor arrest-"Clean Package" Triple I but "Dirty Package" for obtaining
body: (DOT) Mass License Id Fraud Affidavit for documents.docx Norwood Impostor Christopher Piris-Clean Package III Dirty Package for MA RMV.pdf      Hi Team, nice arrest and search warrant here by Off Diego Silva of Norwood PD. This guy was on their radar for sometime and they were able to build enough PC for the arrest and search warrant. Lot of material here so take you time. Note what happened to the stolen identity he purchased. It was good for there being no one in Triple I with that Name, Dob and SSN until he was arrested and booked by Boston PD in 2012 and for what? Class A trafficking at age giving us "0-100" "LONSHP" and "Dude dropped from the sky." The last page in the package, the RMV R1 shows you a "REV" license using the same Name, Dob and SSN however the picture is of a different guy and that was back in 2011. It looks like the Norwood-Piris bought a Lemon. Someone already had tried that identity at the RMV in Mass and was rejected perhaps by a document scanner. Again, no arrest were made, just the wannabe Impostor's money was taken and he was given a temporary paper license.      We are still working this guy, he had been submitted for  DR Facial Recognition and he has a "5 Digit" FBI Number. "Jimmy, you never mentioned a 5 Digit FBI Number in the class?"  Correct, just not enough time to cover especially what we do in Phase Two. But, in the past sometimes a 5 Digit FBI Number-His- (18645PD2)has been found to be older than a 6 Digit FBI Number (123456AB1) and that sometimes when his scanned finger prints are sent to ICE they find an older record on him that we can't see. Sort of like an invisible FN or AR number. He also spent 3 years in MCI here in Mass so he has a lot of info/intel in InMate Web that we are looking at. You have no idea how important phone numbers and addresses can be. Especially phone numbers, if everyone started adding those during the booking process that would be huge. Off. James Scott, Saugus MA PD, Ret-SMSgt, Security Forces, USAFR IdentityTheft Expert/Instructor of the Universal Identity Theft Recognition Program called "Identifying the Impostor".

subject: Brockton, Newton and now Boston PDs: Fraudulent Jeep Purchases with False Puerto Rican License - Arrests and
body: Recoveries      Hi Team, some great work coming your way regarding "Retail Impostors" and the latest victimization of real identities of US Citizens (USC's) from Puerto Rico with Good Credit Ratings! In order to pull off these coming examples not only do you need to steal a real identity but the Complete Package also has to have good enough credit to allow the bad guy to be handed the keys to a brand new $65,000 Jeep. This Retail Impostor also applies to the crew down on the South Shore and Rhode Island who were using real identities and opening up Home Depot accounts. I never did hear where those real identities came from. Someone needs to develop a system combining law enforcement, RMV/DMV and Credit Companies data bases combined and have a product that can vet a Driver's License or State ID on the spot. Banks, retail and now dealerships are getting beat. Imagine if this is what finally fixes all of this fraud, not all the drugs, fatal overdoses and stolen benefits along with voting, but the massive finacial loss of big business. Hmmmm      Reports to follow, below is the well done summary by Chris Neville from the Mass Fusion Center. Attached documents are from Off Chris Perez and Jason Sullivan who did a nice job on this case. So far there has been one copy cat out of Boston PD only a few days after the Newton and Brockton incidents. Off. James Scott, Saugus MA PD, Ret-SMSgt, Security Forces, USAFR IdentityTheft Expert/Instructor of the Universal Identity Theft Recognition Program called "Identifying the Impostor".

subject: , #2018-0H4-006420
body: Tpr. Malhotra,   Hope you are well. I am taking over from Helena Wong on this case. My apologies in advance for the repetition.   Thanks to you, we have a substantial amount of discovery, but Judge Horgan asked us – and seemed doubtful – whether we could prove this case at trial.   Based off your call with Helena, it seems that a number of his aliases were matched on the facial recognition software, he came in for an unrelated hearing, and was arrested. For trial, it would seem like we would need (i) a facial recognition expert who would be able to testify at trial to the different photos being the same person (ii) someone who might be able to explain how the facial recognition software works (iii) you to detail the investigation and tie it all together.   Does that seem right to you? And are you aware of any experts that you have worked with in the past who might be able to serve in roles I and II above?   I’ll be in and out of the office with limited access to email till next Wednesday, but hope to hear from you soon.   Best, Will Ryan Suffolk County DA’s Office

subject: Puerto Rico Fraud Initiative power point illustrating how the nation wide massive fraud can be easily exposed at
attach: The Puerto Rico Fraud initiative and Identifying the Impostor SuperList presentation 2-28-19.pptx
body: little cost. ​     Hi everyone, I added this latest idea to one of my existing power points. This initiative is nothing more than the reverse of what I have been trying to get the Mass RMV to do now for several years. I have asked them to just get a copy of the Puerto Rico DMV database and compare their license holders to all our license holders and identify all the "Double Hits", two people using the same Name, Dob and SSN but there license photo's are not the same. We see this all the time. The Mass RMV is petrified of the numbers. I also asked them to check the Puerto Rico DMV database before issuing any new licenses or State ID's.      So this proposal is nothing more than the reverse, if Puerto Rico or even the DOJ mandated such a program the results would be historic and massive. Off. James Scott, Saugus MA PD, Ret-SMSgt, Security Forces, USAFR IdentityTheft Expert/Instructor of the Universal Identity Theft Recognition Program called "Identifying the Impostor".

subject: DL Photo Request
body: Good Afternoon,   I am an Investigative Specialist with Diplomatic Security Service here in Boston. I was given your contact information by my co-worker SA Eugene Wheelis. I am hoping you could help answer a quick question for me and possible find a DL photo for a Subject of one of our passport fraud cases  .   The SUBJECT,  , has stolen/used at least a dozen different identities over the years. One of those identities is   (DOB:  ). Per NLETS/CJIS, it appears he did have a MA DL in this identity at one point (# S ). However, there doesn’t seem to be any photo attached to the DL that I can find. CJIS also lists the DL # as “No status found on record”. Could you provide any insight as to why there would be a DL# associated with this identity, but there be “no status on record”? In addition, would there be any way to dig up the photo that was associated with this DL #?   DOB:  DL #: S   Thank you for your assistance in this matter. Please let me know if you need any additional information.       Thank you,   Jacqueline Frederick Investigative Specialist Boston Field Office Diplomatic Security Service Department of State FrederickJM@state.gov 617-565-8943   Official - Privacy/PII  UNCLASSIFIED

subject: Imposter Alert
body: Hey Danny, You helped me in the past with an ID issue so I was hoping you might be able to point me in the right direction in a case I'm working. I arrested an individual recently(see attachment) and he had some identity issues. I'm interested in using his booking photo in facial recognition through the RMV to try and locate any other fraud ID's he might be using. Are you familiar with that process or do you know who can help me accomplish that mission?    Paul Martin #3646 Trooper D-4 Massachusetts State Police 326 West Grove Street Middleboro,MA 02346 Tel: 508-947-2222 Fax: 508-923-4115  CONFIDENTIALITY NOTICE  The information contained in this email and any attachment is privileged and confidential law enforcement information. body: Amy -   I was contacted this morning by Tpr. Buccheri (Essex SPDU), below, regarding a Facial Recognition request that was submitted to the Commonwealth Fusion Center on or around 2017  August 4,  pursuant to a Lawrence Homicide (ACISS: 2017-106-394). The CFC, namely myself, assisted in the identification of one of the suspect/person(s) of interest based on a photograph from social media (Instagram). It would appear that the case is going to trial.   Per below, the defense is apparently requesting a copy of my resume with respect to my qualifications, specifically RE: Facial Recognition.   Is this standard? Are there any issues or specific guidelines for cooperating/providing what they request?    Respectfully,   Sean Bender Intelligence Analyst Massachusetts State Police | Commonwealth Fusion Center 470 Worcester Road | Framingham | MA 01702 508-820-2233

Before I send a fraudulent form to all the people that are requested, I just want to find out if it is a data error or why the R1 doesn’t exist in CJIS. There doesn’t seem to be any notes and it is not flagged. The person that it matches up to is S ,  . Also  was entered into Clear and there is no information in there either for him. When you have a chance, can you look into it? Thank you!

body: ATT00001.txt ADA Rodriguez, I sent you the certified copies from the Dominican Republic’s Cedula (their version of the RMV) in a previous email. Those copies included photo and finger prints of the ID thief now known as  . This was confirmed and corroborated by a facial recognition match by CBP/HSI as well as a finger print match by a latent print expert at the Plymouth County Sheriff’s Crime Lab (report below). I realize tomorrow’s motion is for the stop and the extended detention (not the question of identity) but with this amount of evidence that he is not who he says he is maybe we could request the defendant be sworn in prior to the motion and asked to state his given name at birth for the record ? The complaint and docket currently shows the ID victims information ( ). Just a thought. See you in the morning ! subject: Facial Rec Request
body: I ran into this guy the other day on Facebook and knew I worked him in the past, but I can’t remember which identities he used.  Adam Berg who works here believes he used the identity of a , DOB    back in the early 2000s.  I found his license – S  – See pic attached.   Second pic is from a Facebook profile - https://www.facebook.com   - there are no good straight on pics of him there, but I know I worked this guy before.  Adam also said he thinks this guy had at least one more MA identity plus a PA identity.  This impostor was named as   aka   in “Operation Dirty Dope” in 2016 under the NYSP and MA DEA Task Force for a national heroin smuggling ring.   Would you see if you can get any hits on the first pic?  I appreciate it.   Data in public records, commercially available data sources and the internet can contain errors and are generally not totally free from defect.  Data from these sources should not be considered definitively accurate, and all data we provide to you should be independently verified before taking any action based on the results.   Kathy McDonough Criminal Intelligence Specialist NESPIN 124 Grove Street, Suite 105                 Franklin, MA 02038-3159 Direct: 508-530-0566 Tel: 508-528-8200 Fax: (508) 520-3610 (kmcdonough@nespin.riss.net   RISS - A Proven Resource for Law Enforcement                                                                                                                                             If NESPIN has helped you in a recent case please let us know. Your successes are our successes!   This e-mail and any files transmitted with it are confidential or the property of NESPIN, and disclosures or distribution to anyone other than the intended recipient without prior written permission is prohibited.  This e-mail is intended solely for the use of the individual or entity to whom this e-mail is addressed.  The information contained in this message may contain information that is protected by law. If you are not one of the named recipient(s), you are hereby notified that any disclosure, copying, or distribution is strictly prohibited.  If you have reason to believe that you have received this message in error, please notify the sender by replying to the e-mail, calling the sender at 800-343-5682 and deleting this message immediately without disclosure of any of its contents.  Any other use, retention, dissemination, forwarding, printing or copying of this e- mail is strictly prohibited.                As there are potential identities, please directly contact the MSP Fraud Identification Unit with your original request (857-368-9500), as they handle the RMV and licenses for Massachusetts.   Note: The result of a face recognition search is provided by the CFC only as an investigative lead and IS NOT TO BE CONSIDERED A POSITIVE IDENTIFICATION OF ANY SUBJECT. Any possible connection or involvement of any subject to the investigation must be determined through further investigation. subject: Facial rec request using attached PR License
body: Hi Fusion, this might not work but the attached alleged PR License is from a stop by a NH Trooper last night. During his stop he did find a Mass License holder using the same identity but his guy in NH claimed to be the victim of ID Theft and was here for cancer treatment. One thing we found is that the car he was driving, Mass Plates was registered to the same address as the Mass Licensed suspected Impostor.      The only picture we have of the guy that was stopped is off the attached alleged PR License, could you give it a shot in facial rec. Thanks   Off. James Scott, Saugus MA PD, Ret-SMSgt, Security Forces, USAFR Identity Theft Expert/Instructor of the Universal Identity Theft Recognition Program called "Identifying the Impostor".

subject: deadline at noon today —-Herald story on Facial Recognition
body: Hi David,   Do you have any comments on the RMV’s draft responses below?   Questions for RMV to answer:   I'm assuming the RMV makes these photos available to police if they ask for it? The RMV makes digitized images of credential holders available to law enforcement so law enforcement may confirm the veracity of the credentials presented to them. Are there any steps the RMV takes to protect the privacy of individuals? The dissemination of RMV held images is strictly controlled by the federal driver privacy protection act. (As an example, the DPPA prohibits the RMV from releasing license image photos to the media.)   Also, besides the RMV, does the DOT use facial recognition in any way? MassDOT does not use facial recognition beyond the Registry’s use which is strictly controlled by the federal driver privacy protection act and policy guidelines. Thanks,   Judi

subject: Tewksbury PD arrest impostor using real but fraudulently obtained FL License to conceal his real ID and
body: trafficking warrant. ​​     Hi Team, nice pinch here by Tewksbury PD and they all applied a number of the programs concept very well. Note they were not fooled by the Florida License (    and how they checked his finger print results giving them his real ID and Lowell trafficking warrant ( -  This report will be sent to our MSP Division of Homeland Security and Preparedness Fraud Identification Unit, use to be called RMV Compliance and I'm betting he has a number of "flagged" identities in their data base and their facial recognition was catching him forcing him to go out of State for another license. We love those out of State licenses!      Also note the assist from PR PD on finding the true number holder/PR License bearer. Hopefully we can make contact with the TNH and notify him of his stolen identity.  Off. James Scott, Saugus MA PD, Ret-SMSgt, Security Forces, USAFR Identity Theft Expert/Instructor of the Universal Identity Theft Recognition Program called "Identifying the Impostor".

Any assistance you can provide is greatly appreciated     Doug     Official - SBU (Sensitive-Law Enforcement) UNCLASSIFIED    wanted persons file for aliens from the National Crime Information Center (NCIC), which contains information identifying the subject wanted person. Your office is listed as the originating agency. A person applying for a visa to travel to the United States has a name match to the subject wanted person. subject: Previous identified Impostor with valid Mass License who was identified by Lowell PD Det.
body: Burd has made it back into U.S. after deportation.   ​     Hi Team, nice grab here by State Police out in Sturbridge during a traffic stop last Friday night. They were not fooled by the pretty good fraudulent "Real ID" Puerto Rico license. Running that OLN does come back to a PR License under that same Name however the Dob is different. They were also able to get a facial recognition hit using our Fusion Center. The Fusion Center did a nice job getting a hit on two of his previous Mass Licenses under Impostor identities. I hope the Fusion Center is thinking of rolling all our arrest/booking photos from AFISR into the same facial recognition data base! Imagine this same type of data base New England wide! This would be very bad for the bad guys! The access to this type of "Third Thumb Print" my new term, roadside would be amazing. When me and Kathy saw the license photo we knew we has seen this Impostor before and "ICE Man Craig Hamel" recognized him right away as someone he had deported last year.      His real name is   and Lowell still had a felony trafficking warrant out for his arrest. This works out very well when the DA's office does not dismiss the drug case just because the suspect has been deported. All of this gave the Troopers more than enough to take this known impostor into custody. I'm hoping the Secure Communities alarm went off and he was grabbed the following Monday in court. The obvious questions is how was he able to easily make it back into the U.S.? Does his employer, the drug cartel have a clear path of entry we don't know about? He would make a great interview. This Lowell case was also one of our first facial recognition hits using the agencies assigned to the Dominican Rep. Again, this is the same facial recognition the ACLU and Somerville don't want us using! Are we really that concerned about these drug dealers alleged rights?   James Scott, Special Police Officer, Retired-Saugus MA PD Identity Theft Expert/Instructor of the Universal Identity Theft Recognition Program  "Identifying the Impostor".

subject: Previous identified Impostor with valid Mass License who was identified by Lowell PD Det. Burd has made it back
body: into U.S. after deportation. ​     Hi Team, nice grab here by State Police out in Sturbridge during a traffic stop last Friday night. They were not fooled by the pretty good fraudulent "Real ID" Puerto Rico license. Running that OLN does come back to a PR License under that same Name however the Dob is different. They were also able to get a facial recognition hit using our Fusion Center. The Fusion Center did a nice job getting a hit on two of his previous Mass Licenses under Impostor identities. I hope the Fusion Center is thinking of rolling all our arrest/booking photos from AFISR into the same facial recognition data base! Imagine this same type of data base New England wide! This would be very bad for the bad guys! The access to this type of "Third Thumb Print" my new term, roadside would be amazing. When me and Kathy saw the license photo we knew we has seen this Impostor before and "ICE Man Craig Hamel" recognized him right away as someone he had deported last year.      His real name is   and   still had a felony trafficking warrant out for his arrest. This works out very well when the DA's office does not dismiss the drug case just because the suspect has been deported. All of this gave the Troopers more than enough to take this known impostor into custody. I'm hoping the Secure Communities alarm went off and he was grabbed the following Monday in court. The obvious questions is how was he able to easily make it back into the U.S.? Does his employer, the drug cartel have a clear path of entry we don't know about? He would make a great interview. This Lowell case was also one of our first facial recognition hits using the agencies assigned to the Dominican Rep. Again, this is the same facial recognition the ACLU and Somerville don't want us using! Are we really that concerned about these drug dealers alleged rights? James Scott, Special Police Officer, Retired-Saugus MA PD Identity Theft Expert/Instructor of the Universal Identity Theft Recognition Program  "Identifying the Impostor".

subject: Fw :
body: Good Morn ing Lt.  Boyle,  Just  passing t his informatio n alo ng regarding a motor veh icle st op I had  th is past week, du ring  w hich t ime Fusion Cente r assisted me .  I was present ed w ith a PR  Dri ve r's  License and Socia l Security Ca rd  by t he rea r seat passenger  55~ ).  ide ntif ied as  (DOB :- ,  A CJIS  query  of the 55# revea led another party w ith t he same name, DOB, and 55#.  A Il l que ry revea led  two dif fe rent  FBI numbers.  At that point, I be lieved I had  an "Impostor" situat ion .  I reached  out t o the Fusion Cent er for assistance w ith facial recognition, who provided va rious OLNs  based upon t he facial recognition hits .  These OLNS are listed be low and ref lect t he same  party using different names,  DOBs, and 55#:  - - I t he n rece ived  an ema il from PR  Police Department, w hich matched t he PR  License  holder I  had on the stop.  The refore, I kicked  him loose, believing t he passenger may have bee n the  victim of t he Impostor, to wh ich  he no knowledge .  Att ached  in t his ema il are t he RMV photos from PR  and MA, as well as t he PR  License t he  passenger possessed .  Another flag t hat caught my eye was the PR  License itself.  The license  issue dat e was 03/2 1/2017.  I have a PDF  Document from t he Fraud Department in  NYPD,  w hich covers PR  Lice nses issued in 2019.  I noted a f ew in dicators of a pote ntia lly forged  RMV document (missing gold star upper right  hand corner, "Not  for Reai iD Purposes" was not  omitted, "Commonwea lt h of  Puerto Rico" rat he r t han "Governme nt  of Puert o Rico", and the  listed  height and we ight we re typed w it hout  hyphens .  I'm not  sure if t he PR  lice nses issued in 2017 printed with differe nt security measu res,  but  it  came back va lid from PR  RMV.  I be lieve t he passenger I had roadside was t he vict im based  upon t he multiple OLNs  used by t he same part y out  of Lawrence, t he passenger was ab le t o  answer all roadside questions about  Puerto Rico,  and his finger prints were not muti lat ed .  Please let  know if you have any questio ns or need anyt hing furt her.  Respectfully,  Tpr. Da niel Lawlor #4160  Massachusetts Stat e Pol ice  SP  Charlton

subject: Identity Fraud Prosecution - Request for Certified RMV Application
body: Good afternoon:   I’m writing to request certified application records for “ ” (DOB:  ). On 5/6/2019, Officers Bedard and Monk from Salem PD conducted a traffic stop. The person they stopped, the defendant, identified himself as  . He gave a driver’s license for “ ” (S ). After running his information, officers saw 2 FBI numbers for a ” –both numbers coming back with the same name, date of birth, and social security #. One FBI # came back to someone born in Puerto Rico, the other born in the Dominican Republic. One FBI number corresponded with a State ID number which showed a 2009 arrest out of Lynn. Officers requested the booking photo on that case and it matched the person they stopped on 5/6. That FBI # was identified as the defendant.   Puerto Rico Warrants and Extradition sent an RMV photo of the real  ” -who doesn’t look like the defendant. I’m not sure how to request an RMV photo from Puerto Rico, I’m assuming I have to go through the Puerto Rico DMV but let me know if you have any advice on that!   After investigation, officers determined that the defendant is actually named   (DOB:  0). Facial recognition from the DR matched the defendant’s booking photo with someone named “ ”. A facebook search showed a “ ” matching the defendant’s appearance, with an account saying he’s from the DR. Officer’s searched   school districts and found that there is a child living at the same address as the defendant (  01945). That child has a “ ” listed as his father. That child and another also have last names  .”   Defendant also has a driver’s license from the DR  -I have no idea how to get this but I’m assuming it’d be through a DR agency and not our RMV..   I’m requesting the applications because I have to prove that the defendant used another person’s personal information to obtain something of value, here, an identification card. To do that, I would need to prove that   used   information to obtain a MA driver’s license.   Let me know if you need any more information. Thanks,   Kelly Waldo Assistant District Attorney Essex County District Attorney’s Office 56 Federal Street Salem, MA 01960 P: (978) 744-5681 ex.4114 F: (978) 744-9064   The preceding email message (including any attachments) contains information that may be confidential, may be protected by the attorney-client or other applicable privileges, or may constitute non-public information. subject: Identity fraud cases: PR license information
body: Good afternoon Lieutenant Boyle,   One of my colleagues, Kelly Waldo, indicated that you might be my saving grace for a trial I have coming up next week.  I’ve been trying to figure out how to prove my case—it was an investigation after a random query on a license plate when an officer got a double hit on an FBI number.  A few months later, a motor vehicle stop was conducted and my defendant (who claimed to be one “ ” from PR) was arrested for identity fraud.  It took a couple of days, but they were able to obtain his identity based on a hit on facial recognition on a Dominican passport.  I’m on a much tighter timeline than Kelly is—my defendant could post bail but is refusing to give up his passport as a condition of his release.  And by much tighter timeline, I mean, my trial is set for Thursday and I need to provide items to defense attorney by end of the day on Tuesday.   Any chance you think we can pull a miracle on this one?  I have a copy of the Puerto Rican license— just not certified.   Thanks! Haleigh   Assistant District Attorney Haleigh A. Reisman Salem District Court 56 Federal Street Salem, Massachusetts 01970 Email: Haleigh.Reisman@MassMail.State.MA.US Phone: 978-744-5681 ext. 4113   The preceding email message (including any attachments) contains information that may be confidential, may be protected by the attorney-client or other applicable privileges, or may constitute non-public information. It is intended to be conveyed only to the designated recipient(s) named above. If you are not an intended recipient of this message, please notify the sender by replying to this message and then delete all copies of it from your computer system. Any use, dissemination, distribution, or reproduction of this message by unintended recipients is not authorized and may be unlawful.

(HIDTA GROUP 2) Office: (603)628-7411 (Ext 152) Cell: (508)509-1192    The Massachusetts State Police Fraud Identification Unit does a much better job of explaining   the discrepancy, so I have copied Tpr. Malhotra (857-324-0411) on this e-mail and you may wish to reach out to him for additional information if you have questions regarding the registry side of things.  Facial Recognition on that first photograph of your suspect did not return any matches to any    MA licenses or IDs, so it does not appear that he has obtained any new credentials at this point. Similarly, Coplink FaceMatch has returned no close matches to any booking additional photographs in the system. That said, there are a couple of address associated with the suspect that might be useful to you:  - Listed on the Facial Recognition "match" that doesn't return   in CJIS  - Listed on the MA DL for   (DOB:  One of the photos on the   Facebook profile shows your suspect in front of a vehicle bearing MA: 3HD196, registered to     also appears in a bunch of the photos on the   profile (possibly a girlfriend/spouse)? NOTE: The result(s) of Facial Recognition provided by the Commonwealth Fusion Center are to be utilized as   an investigative lead only and are not to be considered a positive, confirmatory identification of any subject. Any possible connection to or involvement of the subject(s) to any active or ongoing investigation must be substantiated through further investigation.   If you believe that a Massachusetts Driver's License or other Identification associated with an ongoing criminal investigation may be fraudulently obtained, please contact the Massachusetts State Police Fraud Identification Section directly - (857) 368-9500. subject: FR Question
body: Hey Lt - Quick question...Ran a Facebook photo through FR and got a possible match...but when I run the same OLN in CJIS it comes back to a different person...What would cause that? Guy on the right is who I'm looking for...but the guy on the bottom is who comes back in CJIS...I can't find any other record for the guy on the right in FR/Coplink/AFIS-R/etc - so right now this photo from Facial Recognition is the only photo I have of him outside of social media...  Thoughts?  Sean Bender  Intelligence Ana lyst  I  Massachusetts State Police  Commonwealth Fusion Center  I  I  470 Worcester Road  Framingham  MA 01702  508-820-2233

subject: Identity Fraud
body: Good afternoon Lt. Boyle:   I am prosecuting an identity fraud case in Salem District Court. My defendant was the passenger in a car that was pulled over. The defendant initially told officers that he was  (DOB:  ) residing at   Officers were able to discover that this Defendant was using a Puerto Rican social security number of  . At some point during this encounter, the Defendant provided officers with a Mass ID card (S ); the number came back with no results in Massachusetts. This ID card was allegedly issued on 12/21/2017 and did not match a license number for the Defendant (S ) The Defendant claimed to have been born in Puerto Rico and had never been issued a PR driver’s license. Officers also reported that the Defendant had a New Hampshire State ID as well as a criminal history in NH. When officers ran the Defendant’s III, two FBI numbers showed with the same demographic information. Officers were able to get in contact with the true   who was born in PR and now resides in the US. The Defendant eventually confessed his true identity to be  ; however, facial recognition has not come back to confirm, so it is unclear as to whether this is truly the Defendant’s name. Apparently, the RMV has initiated proceedings against the Defendant for using a false social security number, but the Defendant defaulted on those matters.   I understand that you are able to get RMV documents to assist us in identity fraud cases. I would like to request the Defendant’s RMV applications as well as any investigative documents that the RMV has collected relative to the Defendant’s identity and use of this name/social security number. If any of the information I have provided you with is unclear please let me know. I can give you more information or forward you a copy of the police report.   Thanks,   Daniel Oste Assistant District Attorney Essex District Attorney's Office 56 Federal Street Salem, MA 01970 Phone: 978.744.5681, x 4117 Fax: 978.744.9064   The preceding email message (including any attachments) contains information that may be confidential, may be protected by the attorney-client or other applicable privileges, or may constitute non-public information. subject: RE  - Question
body: George,   This is displayed because   had hit on the Registry’s Facial Recognition software in July 2017. He had previously used the ID of  ). He had a hearing regarding this on August 1, 2017 and admitted same. The registry took administrative action (suspensions and fines) but he was not criminally charged. Those records have now been merged, so if you run the  number in CJIS it will come back to the  record.   Is his true identity still in question? Sometimes they are able to “get past” the hearings officer with a good packet of fabricated ID documents. Let me know.   I hope this helps. Good luck with your case.   Respectfully,     Tpr. James M. Thompson #3890 Massachusetts State Police Fraud Identification Unit nd 10 Park Plaza 2  floor Boston, MA 02116 Office: (857) 368-9500 Desk: (857) 368-8613 Cell: (857)-324-0410 Fax: (857) 368-0649

subject: Facial Rec
body: Good morning Lt,   Is there anything that can be done for Facial Recognition off of this JPEG license image?     Respectfully,     Sergeant Dana R. Atkinson #2296 Massachusetts State Police Special Operations Motor Vehicle Regulatory Section Vehicle Services Section 25 Newport Ave Ext Quincy, MA 02171   Cell (857) 292-3093 dana.atkinson@pol.state.ma.us      wanted persons file for aliens from the National Crime Information Center (NCIC), which contains information identifying the subject wanted person. Your office is listed as the originating agency. A person applying for a visa to travel to the United States has a name match to the subject wanted person.   Wanted Person: NIC# W560430937 Name:  DOB:  Other name: 2.                      Offense Code: 3533 Offense Code Translation: COCAINE Orig Agency Trans: SP BARRACKS MIDDLEBORO     We are emailing you to ask the following questions:   1) Is this person still wanted by your office?    2) Do you have a photograph or other biographic information you could share with us to be used in determining if our visa applicant is a match to your wanted person? If so, please include in your response to this email.    3) What is the specific crime/crimes subject person is wanted for? Can you please elaborate further on the offense type?   4) Would your office seek international or interstate extradition of this person to your jurisdiction?    Please reply to this email within 3 business days. If we do not receive a reply within 3 business days, we will proceed with processing the visa application to conclusion.   Thank you for your time and attention to this matter.       Amy L. subject: Wanted Person :- , NIC#W560430937
body: Dear Officer:  I am contacting you from the Consulate General of the United States of America in Tijuana, Mexico  in regard to t he subject wanted person . The FBI  has provided the U.S. Department of State with the  wanted persons file for aliens from the National Crime Information Center (NCIC), which contains information identifying the subject wanted person. Your office is listed as the originating agency. A person applying for a visa to travel to the United States has a name match to the subject wanted person.   Wanted Person: NIC# W560430937 Name:  DOB:  Other name: 2.     (A) Other DOB: 1.                    Offense Code: 3533 Offense Code Translation: COCAINE Orig Agency Trans: SP BARRACKS MIDDLEBORO     We are emailing you to ask the following questions:   1) Is this person still wanted by your office?    2) Do you have a photograph or other biographic information you could share with us to be used in determining if our visa applicant is a match to your wanted person? If so, please include in your response to this email.    3) What is the specific crime/crimes subject person is wanted for? Can you please elaborate further on the offense type?   4) Would your office seek international or interstate extradition of this person to your jurisdiction?    Please reply to this email within 3 business days. If we do not receive a reply within 3 business days, we will proceed with processing the visa application to conclusion.   Thank you for your time and attention to this matter.       Amy L. subject: identity theft
body: Good afternoon.  I have an individual that I am investigating for fraud related offenses and identity theft.  While reviewing some of the documents I received back from subpoenas, I discovered that he obtained a State of Mass. Driver’s license using the identity of victim from NY.  The Mass dl # is s  in the name of   who is a disabled male who resides in NY.  I am passing this info along in case Mr.   has committed other fraud related offenses in your state.  Mr.  uses abandoned or for sale property addresses to commit his frauds.  He also utilizes females to open accounts using fake identification and  letters of incorporation that are legit on the face, but the businesses are fictitious and the president is the fake id the female produced at the bank.  Mr.  has a lengthy rap sheet involving weapons offenses and fraud related crimes.  I just want to forward this because he is prolific in the frauds he commits.  If you need anything further, please feel free to reach out.   Thank You   Detective Shawn Ganley #1133 General Investigations Bureau Rahway Police Department 1 City Hall Plaza Rahway, NJ 07065 732-827-2116 sganley@rahwaypolice.com   NOTICE: This e-mail message and any attachment to this e-mail message contain confidential information that may be legally privileged. If you are not the intended recipient, you must not review, transmit, convert to hard copy, copy, use or disseminate this e-mail or any attachments to it. If you have received this e-mail in error, please immediately notify us by return e-mail or by telephone at (732) 827-2200 and delete this message. Please note that if this e-mail message contains a forwarded message or is a reply to a prior message, some or all of the contents of this message or any attachments may not have been produced by the Rahway Police Department. Although the Rahway Police Department attempts to sweep e-mail and attachments for viruses, it does not guarantee that they are virus-free and accepts no liability for any damage sustained as a result of viruses. This notice is automatically appended to each e-mail message leaving the Rahway Police Department.        thought I did hear some crying in the background!   James Scott, Special Police Officer, Retired-Saugus MA PD Identity Theft Expert/Instructor of the Universal Identity Theft Recognition Program  "Identifying the Impostor".

subject: Rhode Island SP impostor arrest wanted out of RI with a valid MA License, slight variation
body: <John.Meyers@massmail.state.ma.us>; George Xenakis-Mass OIG Dep Dir (George.Xenakis@massmail.state.ma.us) <George.Xenakis@massmail.state.ma.us>; Kevin Floster (kevin.floster@state.ma.us) <kevin.floster@state.ma.us>; Logan Davis (logan.r.davis@state.ma.us) <logan.r.davis@state.ma.us> here.        Hi Team, nice arrest here by Trp Shaw out of Rhode Island State Police. He hit right away on the key indicator of that license at age 29 and then the driver not knowing anything about his prior Puerto Rico living history. Access to the Puerto Rico license data base then only made thing worse for him. The slight variation here is using the real but fraudulently obtained Mass License while trying to hide from his gun charges and warrant in Rhode Island. You can also see that he had a prior Rhode Island license number. Imagine the results of just a New England facial recognition program never mind tossing the Puerto Rico DMV data base into that search. I know, you have heard it before. "Jimmy, We can't be arresting thousands of heroin traffickers for license fraud and identity theft."   PS- Trp Garrett Hassett taught Trp Shaw everything he knows!   James Scott, Special Police Officer, Retired-Saugus MA PD Identity Theft Expert/Instructor of the Universal Identity Theft Recognition Program  "Identifying the Impostor".

  James Scott, Special Police Officer, Retired-Saugus MA PD Identity Theft Expert/Instructor of the Universal Identity Theft Recognition Program  "Identifying the Impostor".      sospoliceimages@ilsos.net; vmccarry@ilsos.net; 'iifc@iifc.in.gov' <iifc@iifc.in.gov>; 'intca@dps.state.ia.us' <intca@dps.state.ia.us>; 'fusioncenter@ky.gov' <fusioncenter@ky.gov>; Bales, Meredith R (KSP) <meredith.bales@ky.gov>; blacy@dmv.nv.gov; 'intelligence.fusion@state.nm.us' <intelligence.fusion@state.nm.us>; kihagel@nd.gov; ksnow@sheriff.hamilton-co.org; 'gcfc@gcfc.org' <gcfc@gcfc.org>; pacic@pa.gov; spencerd@horrycounty.org; sdfusioncenter@state.sd.us; 'jcrittenden@utah.gov' <jcrittenden@utah.gov>; vfc@vsp.virginia.gov; wvfusion@wv.gov; stac@milwaukee.gov Subject: Facial Recognition Assistance Federal Fugitive   This office is respectfully requesting facial recognition assistance on the following federal fugitive.  This fugitive has obtained driver’s licenses under 2 different identities in MA, MO, and GA in the past.  In addition to facial recognition, it would also be appreciated if you could run these two names, DOBs, and SSNs in your respective state databases.  This fugitive’s FBI number is unknown at this time.  Please check booking photos also if facial rec is available for booking photos in your state.  He has been wanted since 2007.   Your assistance is greatly appreciated!      ,    Aka     ,  wo MAUSM0100 FID case number 1406417 5’11-6’0 tall on all DLs he’s obtained in the past.  These attached photos are from 1999-2004 Wanted since 2007 on a federal drug warrant from Boston, MA         Neil Sullivan  United States Marshals Service Fugitive Task Force Boston, MA (857) 753-1419 Cell (617) 748-2566 Desk (617) 748-2579 Fax

subject: The Rhode Island SP impostor arrest wanted out of RI with a valid MA License also had a valid U.S. Passport
body: ​     Hi Team, nice heads up by Jacqueline Frederick out of the Boston State Dept Office. She took a look at the arrest made by RISP and queried the names used by the Impostor and got a hit on a valid U.S. Passport. When we talk to each other the bad guys suffer, that is why your reports are so important, yup, talking about you Quincy!!      Your reports go to all the other approximate 1800 students, our RMV, State IG, State ID, Border Patrol all over the place, NYPD, Texas, Louisiana, State Dept, EBT, numerous RMV's and DMV's up and down the coast.      You can get on any plane at any airport with a valid U.S. Passport.  James Scott, Special Police Officer, Retired-Saugus MA PD Identity Theft Expert/Instructor of the Universal Identity Theft Recognition Program  "Identifying the Impostor".

subject: disclaimer
body: Watch, I believe the highlighted version is the latest version of the Facial Recognition disclaimer. Please make sure everyone is using the same standard language.   When requested to perform a facial recognition search and you have a potential match you should EXIT Issuance Facial Recognition and print the subject’s license photo from the CJIS RMV 1 Screen using the issued “S” number or name and DOB.  You may then send to the requesting party the PDF of the CJIS RMV 1 Screen. DO NOT send a photo or any other information obtained from Issuance 360 Facial Recognition. Also, when returning the CJIS RMV 1 PDF, include a disclaimer that states:   The result of a face recognition search is provided by the CFC only as an investigative lead and IS NOT TO BE CONSIDERED A POSITIVE IDENTIFICATION OF ANY SUBJECT. Any possible connection or involvement of any subject to the investigation must be determined through further investigation.     Any analyst who receives a request for information, the results of which indicate that a subject is using a false identification, or otherwise develops a positive indication that a subject may be using a false identity shall fill out the Possible Fraudulent Identification Form and email the form along with supporting documents to: Lt. Chris Boyle, Lt. Brian Brooks, Amy Thibault, Eleanor Smith and Sarah O’Leary. The requesting party should further be instructed to directly contact the MSP Fraud Identification Unit with their original request.      Lieutenant Brian Brooks #2601 Massachusetts State Police Division of Homeland Security and Preparedness Commonwealth Fusion Center 470 Worcester Road Framingham, MA 01702 (W) 508-820-2233 (F) 508-988-7121

subject: Imposter arrest Springfield PD
body: ​Greetings,  Officer's Ryan Thomas/ Joel Lopez (identifying the imposter alum) Springfield PD reporting our first imposter arrest. Originally started as a traffic stop for excessive tint. The driver, which I almost instantly identified as Dominican (my native "tongue" is Puerto Rican) and he also did not deny his nationality, presented a Pennsylvania drivers license in the name of Juan . The vehicle was also registered to this Mr.   Officers received no info back from PA or valid license in MA. Our Detective went to print him while at the station and noticed he was an individual she had recently written a warrant for, but the name didn't match up. He was subsequently identified as Mr.   (has arrests for violent assaults, guns and drug distribution). We're still unsure if this is his true identity. My question is are there an additional charges we could have applied? Also, if there are any "cheat sheet" or slides you could email me so I could re-fresh myself with the indicators to make this process a bit more smoother next time? Any feedback would be appreciated. Thanks.    ​​    license was also not completed.  Lt Chris Boyle, CC'd on the below, is a Trooper assigned to the RMV and will be able to provide further information on the S number and SA number for the attempted licenses.  A query of both provided SSNs through CLEAR provided the below results and attached reports:  SSN:   returned -    -  01105; however, a different DOB is provided:  SSN:   returned negative results  A query of Coplink shows a stop were   is listed as a passenger and provided the same PA license provided to you - report attached.  A query of Coplink for   shows at least 20 PD reports, most from Springfield, including a seizure with heroin. Attached is the summary. AFIS returned photos and prints for  The booking photos from AFIS match those provided in Coplink.  A query of Facial Rec returned negative results for other MA licenses. I would encourage you to reach out to our Fraud ID Unit housed at the RMV -  Lt Chris Boyle - Christopher.P.Boyle@dot.state.ma.us - he will be able to look into the two fraudulent identities and he will also likely be able to contact PA for further information.  Let me know if you have any questions or need anything else.  Respectfully, Intelligence Analyst II Brittany Chandler Massachusetts State Police | Commonwealth Fusion Center 470 Worcester Road | Framingham, MA 01702 Phone: (508) 820-2233 brittany.chandler@pol.state.ma.us CONFIDENTIALITY NOTICE: The information contained in this email and any attachment is privileged and confidential law enforcement information. If you are not the intended recipient, you are hereby notified that any disclosure, dissemination, or copying of this communication is strictly prohibited. subject: Imposter arrest Springfield PD
body: ​Greetings,  Officer's Ryan Thomas/ Joel Lopez (identifying the imposter alum) Springfield PD reporting our first imposter arrest. Originally started as a traffic stop for excessive tint. The driver, which I almost instantly identified as Dominican (my native "tongue" is Puerto Rican) and he also did not deny his nationality, presented a Pennsylvania drivers license in the name of  . The vehicle was also registered to this Mr.   Officers received no info back from PA or valid license in MA. Our Detective went to print him while at the station and noticed he was an individual she had recently written a warrant for, but the name didn't match up. He was subsequently identified as Mr.   (has arrests for violent assaults, guns and drug distribution). We're still unsure if this is his true identity. My question is are there an additional charges we could have applied? Also, if there are any "cheat sheet" or slides you could email me so I could re-fresh myself with the indicators to make this process a bit more smoother next time? Any feedback would be appreciated. Thanks.    ​​

subject: Imposter arrest Springfield PD
body: ​Greetings,    Officer's Ryan Thomas/ Joel Lopez (identifying the imposter alum) Springfield PD reporting our first imposter arrest. Originally started as a traffic stop for excessive tint. The driver, which I almost instantly identified as Dominican (my native "tongue" is Puerto Rican) and he also did not deny his nationality, presented a Pennsylvania drivers license in the name of  . The vehicle was also registered to this Mr.   Officers received no info back from PA or valid license in MA. Our Detective went to print him while at the station and noticed he was an individual she had recently written a warrant for, but the name didn't match up. He was subsequently identified as Mr.   (has arrests for violent assaults, guns and drug distribution). We're still unsure if this is his true identity. My question is are there an additional charges we could have applied? Also, if there are any "cheat sheet" or slides you could email me so I could re-fresh myself with the indicators to make this process a bit more smoother next time? Any feedback would be appreciated. Thanks.

body: <christopher.p.boyle@state.ma .us>;  McDonough, Kathy <kmcdonough@nespin.riss.net>; Monico,  Daniel J <Daniei.J .Monico@ice.dhs.gov>; Hamel, Craig <Craig.Hamel@ice .dhs.gov>;  fusion@pol.state.ma .us         Hi Joel, few things we can do. I forwarded this to Trp Whiteside from Pennsylvania, he can double check that PA License, he may want a picture of that.      I also CC'd the Fusion Center, tomorrow, 10-3, they can run those names he has allegedly used in the past. You should also send them some good booking photo's which may be in AFISR so they can run some facial recognition. I'm betting he had a Mass license at one time.      I also CC'd Lt Boyle, he is in training this week and will jump on it next week. The fraud unit can also do facial recognition and check this guy for a previous license along with that registration.      Kathy is also on vacation and will rip this open next week when she gets back. We will know a lot more in a week or two. I also CC'd a couple of ICE Agents, they can check their data bases.      For additional charges you may have coming RMV fraud 90-24b, also maybe ID Theft, lets see if Kathy can find something in the Puerto Rico DMV database.   James Scott, Special Police Officer, Retired-Saugus MA PD Identity Theft Expert/Instructor of the Universal Identity Theft Recognition Program  "Identifying the Impostor".

subject: [Probable Spam] Imposter -   - Attached Documents and
body: Photos   Sir,   This evening I had a subject come into the New Hampshire DMV for a driver’s license.  Attached are the documents that he produced.  The biggest problem was that a subject matching his biographical information had multiple arrest photos and an active license in Puerto Rico that WAS NOT the person I was looking at.  Further, during an interview, his story was full of more questions than answers. If you could please view the documents I attached as well as the photos and let me know what you think.  Obviously the SS card is laminated which is not great.  The Birth Certificate does shows security threads under UV light.  He claims he was already living in the US and asked ‘a friend’ to get a replacement Birth Certificate for him and send it to him in Boston, MA.  He is currently on parole up here for another 12 months but I strongly believe he is not who he says he is claiming to be.  I had ICE fingerprint him but it only showed his previous arrests under this identity.  He claims he left Puerto Rico sometimes between 2010/2012 and came to Boston.  Quickly he began his criminal history.  I was hoping your access to Facial Recognition may be a help in this investigation. Thank you for your time and anything you can provide.  Trooper First Class Aaron Richards  New Hampshire State Police  DMV Task Force  23 Hazen Drive   Concord, NH 03301  (603) 223-8639 – Office (603) 419-8122 - Cell

subject: [Probable Spam] Imposter -   - Attached Documents and
body: Photos   Sir,   This evening I had a subject come into the New Hampshire DMV for a driver’s license.  Attached are the documents that he produced.  The biggest problem was that a subject matching his biographical information had multiple arrest photos and an active license in Puerto Rico that WAS NOT the person I was looking at.  Further, during an interview, his story was full of more questions than answers. If you could please view the documents I attached as well as the photos and let me know what you think.  Obviously the SS card is laminated which is not great.  The Birth Certificate does shows security threads under UV light.  He claims he was already living in the US and asked ‘a friend’ to get a replacement Birth Certificate for him and send it to him in Boston, MA.  He is currently on parole up here for another 12 months but I strongly believe he is not who he says he is claiming to be.  I had ICE fingerprint him but it only showed his previous arrests under this identity.  He claims he left Puerto Rico sometimes between 2010/2012 and came to Boston.  Quickly he began his criminal history.  I was hoping your access to Facial Recognition may be a help in this investigation. Thank you for your time and anything you can provide.  Trooper First Class Aaron Richards  New Hampshire State Police  DMV Task Force  23 Hazen Drive   Concord, NH 03301  (603) 223-8639 – Office (603) 419-8122 - Cell

body: (POL) <brian.brooks@pol.state.ma.us>; Boyle, Christopher (POL) <Christopher.Boyle@pol.state.ma.us>; Thibault, Amy (POL) <amy.thibault@pol.state.ma.us>; Smith, Eleanor (POL) <Eleanor.Smith@pol.state.ma.us>; O'Leary, Sarah (POL) <Sarah.OLeary@pol.state.ma.us>; Fisher, Christine (POL) <christine.fisher@pol.state.ma.us>; Gawron, Stephen (POL) <stephen.gawron@pol.state.ma.us>   Good evening. Attached is the possible fraudulent identification form. Trooper Jennifer Penton sent an image while she was roadside. The subject gave Trooper Penton a CT license. Brittany Chandler found four possible identities including a Florida license. When I came in, the Florida license image was ran and found five possible MA licenses, of which two were already found by Brittany Chandler. Listed below are the possible identities found. Attached are the Florida license photo, images that Tpr. Jennifer Penton sent, possible R1’s for review, and the Possible Identification Form. If there is any additional information needed, please let me know. Thanks.   License # Name Date of birth SS# Status Warrants No status 0 none Suspended 2 Revoked 0 Revoked 2 Suspended 0     Marcy Bennett Intelligence Analyst Commonwealth Fusion Center 470 Worcester Road Framingham, MA 508-820-2233     CONFIDENTIALITY NOTICE: The information contained in this email and any attachment is privileged and confidential law enforcement information  If you are not the intended recipient, you are hereby notified that any disclosure, dissemination, or copying of this communication is strictly prohibited  If you have received this email in error, please call (978) 451-3700 immediately

subject: Discovery for Commonwealth v.   -   - Incident #
body: Good afternoon trooper,   I’ve been assigned the case against   (AKA  ) and I am reaching out regarding the discovery for this case. I wanted to ask if you could provide me with any and all of the material you collected as part of your investigation. In particular, I am wondering if you have any fingerprints, birth certificates, facial recognition, supplemental reports, and information on the defendant’s true name. Reading your report, it also appears that you were able to pull data from the Brockton and Taunton RMVs. Would you be able to provide that information as well?   I recall that I sent, or will send, you a summons for December 17, 2019 on another case. This case is on for a pretrial hearing tomorrow, so I will ask the court to put this on for the same date so you don’t have to come back here twice.   Best Andrew   Andrew S. Haag Legal Assistant Suffolk County District Attorney’s Office Boston Municipal Court – Central Division 24 New Chardon St Boston, MA 02114 Phone: 617-396-5785 Fax: 617-227-4731

subject: Narcotics  Investigation
body: Good  Evening Sergeant Boyle,  I  was wondering  if  your team was aware of the following  individual:  MA License # :  Name:  DOB:  SSN:  We currently have an open investigation  into him for distribution of fentanyl.  I  have been  working closely with Kathy McDonough from NESPIN and have identified  him as an  imposter. I  am in the process of completing the imposter portion of the report while we  continue our narcotics end of the investigation. The true number holder is possibly living in  Pennsylvania whom I  am attempting to track down and speak with. I  am also attempting to  figure out his true identity in the next week or so before we wrap up the investigation.  Just wondering if you want me to stay in touch with you about the open drug investigation  and was  wondering if I  should continue to file an immediate threat as soon as we wrap up  our case?  I  appreciate your time as always.  -Jim  James P. Bedard  Detective  Salem Police Department  95 Margin Street  Salem, MA 01970  Phone: (978) 744-0171  ext. 50309  Cell Phone: (978) 778-8253  Fax: (978) 740-5180  Please note the Massachusetts Secretat1' of State's office has determined that most emails to  and from municipal officials are public records. For more information please refer to:  http://www.sec state ma.us!pre!prejrlx htm.  Please consider the environment before printing this email.

subject: Potential Nantucket PD Imposter
body: ma.gov>> <cgraham@nespin riss net<mailto:cgraham@nespin.riss.net>> Hello, Here is the information on the potential imposter that was arrested for OUI on Nantucket over the weekend. There are 3 FBI numbers using the same identity. One is the Nantucket arrest. There is also somebody that was arrested in Rhode Island for narcotics earlier this year. I figure that at least one is the imposter (if not all). I’ve reached out to Providence PD for a booking photo of their arrest but haven’t heard back yet. I have not been able to get in touch with anybody from Puerto Rico to get a picture of their license holder. I am looking for any help that you could give me in trying to sort this out. My cell is  . Thank you in advance for your help. subject: Potential Nantucket PD Imposter
body: ma.gov>> <cgraham@nespin riss net<mailto:cgraham@nespin.riss.net>> Hello, Here is the information on the potential imposter that was arrested for OUI on Nantucket over the weekend. There are 3 FBI numbers using the same identity. One is the Nantucket arrest. There is also somebody that was arrested in Rhode Island for narcotics earlier this year. I figure that at least one is the imposter (if not all). I’ve reached out to Providence PD for a booking photo of their arrest but haven’t heard back yet. I have not been able to get in touch with anybody from Puerto Rico to get a picture of their license holder. I am looking for any help that you could give me in trying to sort this out. My cell is  . Thank you in advance for your help. subject: Nantucket PD arrest what we call an "Impostor" aka "Game of Clones" identity thief all the way from the South
attach: Nantucket imposter arrest report, Texas license.pdf Nantucket Triple I    ,  , 3 in III.pdf
body: West-Texas      Hi Team, over the years we have developed a significant network of really smart and hardworking Officers, Troopers, Agents, Analyst, etc from all over the United States. We are able to reach out to these individuals when we see that our suspected Impostor has been outside of New England which is the case here out of the Island of Nantucket. Last week they had an OUI arrest involving a valid Texas License and what appeared to be a Puerto Rico identity based on the SSN. What is a guy with a gun and stolen car history in California doing allegedly working on Nantucket driving around with a fraudulent obtained Texas License and vehicle registration. Our True Number Holder may be the guy in jail in Rhode Island.       The attached report from Det. Chris Kelly who came to the class several years ago shows that he reviewed an arrest report from the weekend. In only a few minutes after reviewing the report he started applying the program and soon realized he had a potential impostor. After doing a great job of putting the case together he reached out for help. I took a look and what did I see? Take a look at my marked up "Triple I", I saw three potential Impostors and the Texas License Holder who had been arrested had a "Flag" attached to his TX License print out indicating possible fraud.      I knew who to reach out to right away because of our friends from Border Patrol in Puerto Rico. They had introduced me to a HSI Agent out in Laredo TX who was very much involved in an ongoing Operation called "Game of Clones". Just another name for "Identifying the Impostor", yup this is a nation wide identity theft problem. I'm hoping to get Agent Roberto Melendez to speak at the upcoming Arizona classes in Feb 2020!!! How is that for a hint!      You will want to save a copy of this report. It is well written, flows very nicely and illustrates in detail the probable cause. The only thing I would add in the future is some sort of language that the Defendant was afforded every opportunity to call or contact any relative in order to prove he was really who he said he was and failed to make any calls, etc...      So it's up to the court now on Monday morning. --  James Scott, Instructor, Identifying the Impostor-The Universal Identity Theft Recognition Program Special Officer Saugus MA PD, retired full time. Retired SMSgt USAFR Security Forces "The fatal error for the Impostor is to have an interaction with an Officer trained in "Identifying the Impostor."   Web site - identifyingtheimpostor.com   court asked me to flag to you the issue regarding the defendant’s true identity in this case. On paragraph 3 of your report, you indicate that the defendant’s alias is   and that his true name is  . However, the defendant is charged under  . Should he have been charged under his   name?   The next court date for this case is December 17, 2019 and we have issued you a summons for that date. But if you could send me any information you might have on this identity issue prior to that date, that would be very helpful.   Thank you Andrew

body: Good Afternoon, Can you please Facial Rec this party for us?  The case # 2019-TDU-47. Thank you, John  Good Afternoon,     A facial recognition search of   (DOB:  ) resulted in potential match to a   (DOB: ).  Both records had different social security numbers and OLNs, but had very similar facial features and the same address.  We explored the possibility that   and   are twin brothers, however, we were not able to confirm.  Please note that further investigation into this matter is needed in order to positively confirm fraudulent activity.     Please reach out to MSP's Fraud ID section at 857-368-9500 - they may be able to help get to the bottom of whether both records reflect twins or fraud, etc.     The Commonwealth Fusion Center is providing this information as a result of a search utilizing the MA-RMV facial recognition system.  The results are NOT being provided as a form of positive identification of any subject, they are considered advisory in nature as an investigative lead only and do NOT establish probably cause, without further investigation.  Any possible connection between the information provided and any identified individual must be determined and validated through further investigation or corroboration which shall be the sole responsibility of the requestor. subject: CW v.   -   - 2019-134-5499-3
body: Good evening trooper,   I wanted to reach out to you regarding the above-mentioned case. I believe you may have previously been working with ADA Boulanger on this case, but it has been reassigned to me. I see in my a good chunk of discovery on this case, which looks like a lot of RMV materials and documents showing the conflicting ID. However, I wanted to see if you might have any additional discovery. In particular, do you have anything on the defendant’s birth certificate, any facial recognition used in the case, or fingerprints.   The case is currently scheduled for a pretrial date tomorrow, though because I did not reach out sooner, I did not summons you for the date. I am just trying to get a sense of if there is any else that might be out there.   Thanks Andrew   Andrew S. Haag Assistant District Attorney Suffolk County District Attorney’s Office Boston Municipal Court – Central Division 24 New Chardon St Boston, MA 02114 Phone: 617-396-5785 Fax: 617-227-4731
